entry.et: Middle English, from Old English weall; akin to Middle High German wall; both from Latin vallum rampart, from vallus stake, palisade; perhaps akin to Old Norse vǫlr staff wale

def.dt: :a high thick masonry structure forming a long rampart or an enclosure chiefly for defense often used in plural
:a masonry fence around a garden, park, or estate
:a structure that serves to hold back pressure (as of water or sliding earth)
:one of the sides of a room or building connecting floor and ceiling or foundation and roof
:the side of a footpath next to buildings
:an extreme or desperate position or a state of defeat, failure, or ruin the surrounded troops had their backs against the wall
:a material layer enclosing space the wall of a container heart walls
:something resembling a wall (as in appearance, function, or effect)
:something that acts as a barrier or defense a wall of reserve tariff wall
:crazy the plan was off the wall
:into a state of intense agitation, annoyance, or frustration the noise drove me up the wall
:to provide, cover with, or surround with or as if with a wall wall in the garden
:to separate by or as if by a wall walled off half the house
:immure walled the monster up within the tomb E. A. Poe
:to close (an opening) with or as if with a wall

entry.et: Middle English (Scots) wawlen, probably from Middle English wawil- (in wawil-eghed walleyed)

def.dt: :to roll in a dramatic manner
:to roll (one's eyes) in a dramatic manner
:fresco
:plate 5
:an electric receptacle in a wall
:a rock through which a fault or vein runs
:any of several Old World herbs (genus Diplotaxis) of the mustard family
:a yellow-flowered European herb (D. tenuifolia) naturalized in North America

entry.et: Wall Street, New York City, site of the New York Stock Exchange

def.dt: :the influential financial interests of the United States economy
:a person who is involved in Wall Street
